page.title: 02Quatford Area
page.content: The land to the south of St.Mary's school is mainly farm land consisting of arable,pasture and woodland, much of which is the remains of the old forest of Morfe. In section 91/72,73,74,75 we found a total of 45 arable and 43 pasture fields. The whole area lies on a mass of sandstone laid long ago by some ancient sea. The trees are mainly coniferous because of the shallow soil,few deciduous trees grow here. The land is dry,well drained by the sandstone beneath,so pasture and crops often turn yellow in the long hot summers. Quatford Wood is an example of an ancient forest, two thirds coniferous,one third deciduous. Some of the children walked this area: Quatford has many old houses,they and their setting have changed little since they were built by the old road.
